thread.title: H.S. girls volleyball: Fort Lee set for Bergen County tournament
thread.title_full: H.S. girls volleyball: Fort Lee set for Bergen County tournament

title: H.S. girls volleyball: Fort Lee set for Bergen County tournament
text:
Pages: 1 2 > display on one page 
Fort Lee can place an official check mark next to the first of its three goals for the girls volleyball season: qualify for the Bergen County tournament. 
The selection and seeding meeting for the 41st tournament was Tuesday night at NV/Old Tappan and the Bridgewomen received the 27th seed in the 32-team field. 
“It’s a chance to play somebody good,” said coach John Ziemba, whose team plays at No. 6 Tenafly in Saturday’s opening round, “a chance to get a little recognition, and to help us get better so that hopefully we can finish off the league.” 
As expected, unbeaten NV/Old Tappan received the No. 1 seed, two-time defending champion Immaculate Heart is No. 2, unbeaten River Dell No. 3, Paramus No. 4 and NV/Demarest No. 5. 
Fort Lee’s opportunity to compete in the Bergen tournament for the first time this decade is significant, surpassed only by the chance to win a division title for the first time in 18 years. 
Fort Lee (13-6) sits atop the Big North American Division. The Bridgewomen are 5-0 in the American with three matches remaining, thanks to wins over fellow county tournament entries Cliffside Park and Dumont, as well as Ridgefield Park, which has dominated the division for several years. 
“I think we have an opportunity to win,” said senior hitter Stella Vaso, who came to Fort Lee from Italy as a sophomore and is the American Division’s top player. “I really hope we’re going to do well and win. It would be an honor for us to win after a long time.” 
Ziemba credited two changes for the Bridgewomen enjoying their best season in several years. 
1. The introduction three years ago of a seventh/eighth-grade team. That middle-school experience allowed sophomores such as setter Brianna Forness and hitter Sophia Park to join Vaso and junior hitter Catherine Liapes this season on varsity. 
“They wouldn’t be playing varsity if we didn’t have the seventh/eighth-grade team,” said Ziemba, who this month earned his 200th career victory. 
2. The Bridgewomen participated in Tenafly’s summer camp, which helped avoid the slow starts that often paved the way for a losing season. 
“Everyone who went there improved a lot,” said the 5-foot-9 Vaso, “and that was really helpful.” 
Fort Lee’s final goal is to earn a first-round home game in next month’s Group 2 tournament. Before that, though, the Bridgewomen will focus their attention on this week’s division rematch with Cliffside Park, then the Bergen tournament. 
“Bergen County volleyball is tough, it’s incredible,” said Ziemba, whose county has won 12 of the first 13 Tournament of Champions titles, with IHA winning the past four. “The bottom line is we’re happy where we are right now, and we want to finish the league off, and hopefully we can have a good game on Saturday.” 

Bergen County girls volleyball tournament schedule 
First round by Saturday 
(32) Park Ridge at (1) NV/Old Tappan 
(17) Northern Highlands at (16) Becton 
(25) Lyndhurst at (8) Mahwah 
(24) Garfield at (9) Bogota 
(29) Wallington at (4) Paramus 
(20) Glen Rock at (13) Pascack Valley 
(28) Dumont at (5) NV/Demarest 
(21) Midland Park at (12) Fair Lawn 
(31) Hasbrouck Heights at (2) Immaculate Heart © 2015 North Jersey Media Group Tags:
